name: Aluminium foil
info: Thin, flexible sheet of aluminum often used for wrapping food.
disposal: Rinse and recycle if clean; otherwise, dispose of in general waste.
facts: Aluminium can be recycled indefinitely without losing quality.

name: Bottle cap
info: Plastic or metal caps used to seal bottles.
disposal: Check with local recycling programs; some require caps removed.
facts: Small bottle caps often escape sorting machines, causing pollution.

name: bottle
info: Plastic or glass containers for beverages and other liquids.
disposal: Rinse and recycle; glass and plastic should be separated.
facts: A plastic bottle can take up to 450 years to decompose.

name: Broken glass
info: Shattered glass pieces from bottles or windows.
disposal: Wrap in thick paper and dispose of in a separate bin to avoid injury.
facts: Glass is 100% recyclable but dangerous if not handled properly.

name: Can
info: Metal beverage or food container.
disposal: Rinse and recycle; aluminum cans are widely accepted.
facts: Recycling one aluminum can saves enough energy to run a TV for 3 hours.

name: Carton
info: Paper-based liquid containers for milk, juice, etc.
disposal: Rinse and check if your local recycling program accepts cartons.
facts: Cartons are made of paper, plastic, and aluminum, requiring special recycling processes.

name: Cigarette
info: Used cigarette butts with filters.
disposal: Dispose of in general waste; never litter as they are non-biodegradable.
facts: Cigarette filters contain plastic and take up to 10 years to decompose.

name: Lid
info: Plastic or metal covering for cups or containers.
disposal: Check local recycling; plastic lids often need to be separated.
facts: Plastic lids are among the top ocean pollutants.

name: Other litter
info: Uncategorized waste materials.
disposal: Dispose of in general waste.
facts: Miscellaneous litter contributes to land and marine pollution.

name: Other plastic
info: Various plastic items not classified elsewhere.
disposal: Check the plastic type and follow local recycling rules.
facts: Over 300 million tons of plastic are produced each year, only a fraction gets recycled.

name: Paper
info: Thin material made from wood pulp.
disposal: Recycle clean paper; avoid recycling greasy or wet paper.
facts: Recycling one ton of paper saves 17 trees and 7,000 gallons of water.

name: Plastic bag - wrapper
info: Thin plastic packaging material.
disposal: Not always recyclable curbside; check drop-off locations.
facts: Plastic bags take 500+ years to degrade and cause severe ocean pollution.

name: Plastic container
info: Rigid plastic packaging for food and products.
disposal: Rinse and recycle; check for plastic resin codes.
facts: Only about 9% of all plastic waste ever produced has been recycled.

name: Pop tab
info: Aluminum pull tabs from cans.
disposal: Recyclable along with aluminum cans.
facts: Many organizations collect pop tabs for charity fundraising.

name: Straw
info: Plastic tube used for drinking beverages.
disposal: Dispose of in general waste; not commonly recyclable.
facts: Plastic straws are one of the most common pollutants in oceans.

name: Styrofoam piece
info: Small piece of polystyrene foam.
disposal: Dispose of in general waste; very few recycling centers accept it.
facts: Styrofoam takes hundreds of years to decompose and is harmful to wildlife.

name: Unlabeled litter
info: Waste items with unknown material composition.
disposal: Dispose of in general waste.
facts: Unlabeled litter increases sorting challenges in waste management.

name: Umbrella
info: Collapsible canopy used for protection from rain or sun.
disposal: Dispose of in general waste; difficult to recycle due to mixed materials.
facts: Umbrellas often contain metal, fabric, and plastic, making them hard to recycle.

name: Handbag
info: Bag used for carrying personal items, made from leather, fabric, or plastic.
disposal: Donate if usable; otherwise, dispose of in general waste.
facts: Many handbags contain synthetic materials that do not biodegrade easily.

name: Tie
info: Cloth accessory worn around the neck.
disposal: Donate if in good condition; otherwise, dispose of in general waste.
facts: Ties are often made from synthetic fibers, making them non-biodegradable.

name: Suitcase
info: Luggage used for carrying clothes and personal belongings.
disposal: Donate if in good condition; otherwise, dispose of as bulk waste.
facts: Most suitcases contain a mix of plastic, fabric, and metal, making recycling difficult.

name: Frisbee
info: Plastic disc used for recreational throwing games.
disposal: Dispose of in general waste unless made of recyclable plastic.
facts: Most Frisbees are made of durable plastic, which takes hundreds of years to decompose.

name: Skis
info: Long, flat devices used for skiing on snow.
disposal: Donate if usable; otherwise, check for local bulk waste disposal programs.
facts: Skis are often made of a combination of fiberglass, plastic, and metal, making them hard to recycle.

name: Snowboard
info: Board used for snowboarding, typically made of wood, plastic, and metal.
disposal: Donate if in good condition; otherwise, dispose of as bulk waste.
facts: Snowboards contain composite materials that are not easily recyclable.

name: Sports Ball
info: Ball used in various sports like football, basketball, and soccer.
disposal: Dispose of in general waste; some rubber-based balls may be recyclable.
facts: Sports balls often contain synthetic leather and rubber, making them difficult to recycle.

name: Kite
info: Lightweight flying object made of paper, fabric, or plastic.
disposal: Recycle if made of paper; plastic kites should be disposed of in general waste.
facts: Traditional paper kites are biodegradable, unlike plastic-based kites.

name: Baseball Bat
info: Wooden or metal bat used in baseball.
disposal: Recycle metal bats at scrap metal facilities; wooden bats should go in general waste or be repurposed.
facts: Wooden baseball bats can sometimes be composted if untreated.

name: Baseball Glove
info: Leather glove used for catching baseballs.
disposal: Donate if in good condition; otherwise, dispose of in general waste.
facts: Most baseball gloves are made of treated leather, making them difficult to recycle.

name: Skateboard
info: Board with wheels used for skating.
disposal: Donate if usable; otherwise, dispose of in bulk waste collection.
facts: Skateboards are made of multiple materials like wood, metal, and plastic, making recycling complex.

name: Surfboard
info: Board used for surfing, usually made of foam, fiberglass, and resin.
disposal: Check for recycling programs; otherwise, dispose of in bulk waste.
facts: Most surfboards are not recyclable due to their composite materials.

name: Tennis Racket
info: Sports equipment with a handle and mesh used for playing tennis.
disposal: Donate if usable; metal frames can be recycled.
facts: Older wooden rackets are harder to recycle than modern metal or composite ones.

name: Chair
info: Furniture piece used for seating.
disposal: Donate if in good condition; otherwise, dispose of in bulk waste collection.
facts: Chairs made of wood or plastic are difficult to recycle.

name: Couch
info: Large furniture piece used for seating multiple people.
disposal: Donate if in good condition; otherwise, dispose of in bulk waste.
facts: Couches contain fabric, wood, and foam, making recycling difficult.

name: Book
info: Collection of written or printed pages bound together.
disposal: Recycle paper books if not laminated or soiled.
facts: Recycling books helps save trees and reduces landfill waste.

name: Clock
info: Device used to measure and display time.
disposal: Dispose of electronic clocks as e-waste; mechanical clocks can be recycled based on materials.
facts: Electronic clocks contain circuits and batteries that should be properly disposed of.

name: Vase
info: Container used for holding flowers, often made of glass, ceramic, or plastic.
disposal: Recycle if made of glass or plastic; ceramic vases may not be recyclable.
facts: Glass vases can be melted and reused indefinitely.

name: Scissors
info: Hand-operated cutting tool.
disposal: Recycle as scrap metal if fully metal; plastic-handled ones should be disposed of in general waste.
facts: Metal scissors can be melted down and reused.

name: Hair Dryer
info: Electrical device used for drying hair.
disposal: Dispose of as electronic waste; do not throw in general waste.
facts: Hair dryers contain electronic components that need proper recycling.

name: Toothbrush
info: Oral hygiene tool with a handle and bristles.
disposal: Dispose of in general waste; some brands offer recycling programs.
facts: Plastic toothbrushes take hundreds of years to decompose.

name: Banana
info: A tropical fruit with a soft, edible interior and a thick peel.
disposal: Compost banana peels; avoid throwing them in regular waste.
facts: Banana peels decompose within 2-5 weeks, enriching soil with potassium and phosphorus.

name: Apple
info: A nutritious fruit with a crisp texture and edible skin.
disposal: Compost apple cores and peels for eco-friendly disposal.
facts: Apple waste decomposes in about 2 months and provides nitrogen to compost.

name: Orange
info: A citrus fruit rich in vitamin C with a thick, inedible peel.
disposal: Compost orange peels or dry them for natural air fresheners.
facts: Citrus peels take longer to decompose due to natural oils but are great for composting in moderation.

name: Sandwich
info: A food item made of bread filled with various ingredients.
disposal: Compost bread, vegetables, and organic fillings; dispose of plastic wraps separately.
facts: Stale bread can be repurposed into croutons or composted to prevent food waste.

name: Hot Dog
info: A processed sausage in a bun, often with condiments.
disposal: Compost leftover bread and organic toppings; avoid composting processed meat.
facts: Bread decomposes quickly, but processed meat can attract pests if not disposed of properly.

name: Pizza
info: A baked dish with a dough base topped with cheese, tomato sauce, and other ingredients.
disposal: Compost crust and vegetable toppings; cheese and meat should be disposed of in general waste.
facts: Greasy pizza boxes are not recyclable but can be composted if they are free of excessive cheese or oil.

name: Donut
info: A fried or baked sweet dough treat often covered in icing or sugar.
disposal: Compost plain donuts; icing and sprinkles should be disposed of separately.
facts: Sugary foods like donuts break down quickly but may attract pests in compost bins.

name: Cake
info: A baked dessert made from flour, sugar, eggs, and butter.
disposal: Compost cake without heavy icing; dispose of plastic decorations separately.
facts: Cake decomposes fast, adding moisture to compost piles.

name: Bottle
info: A container used for holding liquids, usually made of plastic or glass.
disposal: Recycle glass and plastic bottles properly; avoid throwing them in organic waste.
facts: Plastic bottles take over 450 years to decompose, while glass bottles can be recycled indefinitely.

name: Wine Glass
info: A delicate glassware item used for serving wine.
disposal: Do not recycle broken wine glasses; dispose of them in general waste.
facts: Glassware has different melting points than bottles, making them non-recyclable in regular glass bins.

name: Cup
info: A small container used for drinking beverages.
disposal: Paper cups with plastic lining are not recyclable; compost plain paper cups if possible.
facts: Most disposable cups contain plastic coatings, making them non-recyclable.

name: Fork
info: A utensil with prongs used for eating solid foods.
disposal: Metal forks can be recycled; plastic forks should go in general waste.
facts: Plastic cutlery is among the top pollutants found in oceans.

name: Knife
info: A sharp utensil used for cutting food.
disposal: Recycle metal knives safely; wrap and dispose of broken knives in general waste.
facts: Sharp objects should be handled carefully during disposal to prevent injury.

name: Spoon
info: A rounded utensil used for eating or stirring food.
disposal: Recycle metal spoons; plastic spoons should be disposed of in general waste.
facts: Plastic spoons are difficult to recycle and often end up in landfills or oceans.

name: Bowl
info: A round dish used for holding food or liquids.
disposal: Recycle glass and plastic bowls; ceramic bowls are non-recyclable.
facts: Broken ceramic bowls should be disposed of carefully, as they cannot be recycled with regular glass.
